Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Catalytic Conversion of Lignocellulosic Biomass into Glucose using Green Solvents
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is the production of low cost glucose from biomass. The production of cost-competitive biofuels from biomass has been a significant industrial challenge due to the high cost of fractionation and conversion into sugars and biofuels. A renewable solvent has been shown to enable the efficient fractionation of the biomass into three components, which can be further processed within the solvent into higher value products. One of the component parts of biomass can be further processed to produce glucose. The ability to co-produce glucose with one or two other high value products from a single source of biomass provides a significant economic advantage. With success, this biorefinery concept will enable the production of cost competitive glucose for biofuels from a variety of biomass types.

The objectives of this Phase I research project are to demonstrate the low cost production of glucose from cellulosic sugar in gamma-valerolactone and use the by-products from this process to produce the gamma-valerolactone. The first step in the process, fractionation of the biomass, has been demonstrated at bench scale using multiple types of biomass. The solvent solubilizes the five-carbon carbohydrates (C5) and lignin components leaving a solid cellulose. Production of the C5 carbohydrates in the renewable solvent has been proven to be advantageous versus aqueous systems as the increased reactivity of acids in these solvents allows for the utilization of low concentration of acid, short residence times (minutes) and low temperatures. The lignin is preserved in these mild conditions and precipitated out; while the C5 carbohydrate is converted into furfural. This project proposes to apply the same solvent advantages in the conversion of cellulose to sugars delivering monomeric glucose at low cost. The solvent utilized in the process will be produced from by-products, demonstrating that the process can be self-sustainable and improve the carbon utilization. The glucose produced will be similar to the glucose produced from corn or sugarcane and will be competitive in price.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Glucan Biorenewables is commercializing a game-changing biomass fractionation technology, the TriVersa ProcessTM. Using gamma-valerolactone (GVL) as a solvent, GlucanBio simultaneously co-produces three high-end products, high purity cellulose, furfural, and technical lignin. The cellulose is utilized to produce dissolving pulp or be converted into sugars, the hemicellulose is converted into furfural without an intermediate separation, and the lignin can be upgraded to carbon products. By utilizing a larger percentage of the lignocellulosic biomass to produce high end products, product revenues increase and unit production costs decrease, which is the main advantage of the process. 

 

With the support of NSF’s SBIR Phase I and Phase IB funding, we have demonstrated that using a technology similar to that used in the pulp and paper industry we can produce high purity cellulose from lignocellulosic biomass (white birch) in a single step while working at lower temperatures, lower pressures, and shorter times. Using GVL as a solvent enhances the reactivity of acids such as sulfuric acid, which allows us to remove the hemicellulose and the lignin almost completely without degrading any of the fractions. Because lignin is highly soluble in the GVL solvent at the process conditions, we can process biomass at high loadings and still produce high purity cellulose while reducing the solvent utilization and energy requirements.

 

The project has demonstrated that recent scientific advancements, published in peer review journals, related with the utilization of organic solvents to deconstruct, fractionate, and upgrade lignocellulosic biomass more effectively, can be directly applied to a commercial process. This should encourage more fundamental research focusing on a better understanding of the effect of solvents on biomass conversion reactions, which enables the concept of an integrated bio-refinery that works in a similar manner as a petroleum refinery, but uses renewable feedstocks.

 

During this project, we have optimized the process conditions to fractionate the lignocellulosic biomass while minimizing the cellulose degradation and achieving near complete removal of the hemicellulose and lignin. This allows us to produce a high purity cellulose retaining critical properties such as viscosity. Resultanly, it can be used to produce dissolving pulp, a specialty grade of cellulose that is utilized to produce textiles, pharmaceuticals, cellophane, and food additives.

 

The high purity cellulose can also be converted into soluble sugars using GVL/water as a solvent and a low concentration of acid (0.005 M sulfuric acid). The reaction only takes minutes at temperatures around 200°C and does not require the use of enzymes. The sugars can be further upgraded to specialty chemicals, such as HMF or levulinic acid without separating them from the GVL or they can be separated into an aqueous phase to be used in other processes. By adding an additional step, the soluble sugars can be converted into monomeric sugars (i.e. glucose) that can be used as a feedstock for microbial fermentation processes, i.e. production of cellulosic ethanol.

 

During the production of the sugars from the cellulose, parts of the sugars are converted into HMF and levulinic acid. These two chemicals can easily be converted into the solvent, GVL, improving the carbon efficiency of the process. This GVL is used as make-up solvent to compensate for the minimal losses that are associated with the process and making the process close looped and self-sustainable. During the Phase I and Phase IB work, we have demonstrate that a catalyst based on RuSn can be used to hydrogenate levulinic acid to GVL for more than 15 days without observing any deactivation.
